awd_abstract_narration:
In this project the investigators will address the processes through which stratified societies and city-states emerge and the mechanisms for the formation of citizenship and democracy. Emphasis will be placed upon the role of non-elite in the emergence of democracy.  Bioarchaeology, the study of human remains in archaeological and historical contexts, is well suited to give voice to the non-elite, often the silent people of the past, who infrequently appear in written sources, art, and architecture. By linking science to the humanities, this project will combine a variety of lines of evidence to shed light into the life conditions and mortuary treatment of the non-elite and the outsiders in early city-state communities. In addition, this project will enhance the visibility of females in the profession. It will also build a number of collaborations between US and non-US academic institutions and will thus provide research venues for dissertations and postdoctoral research positions expanding the range and impact of US archaeological activities. It will also provide significant training for undergraduate, graduate, and junior professionals in the field of bioarchaeology and related scientific methods, such as chemical analysis for the reconstruction of past diets and population movement. Furthermore, this project will significantly advance the cause of cross-disciplinary research and analysis. At the same time, through its pioneering approach to the recovery, management, and dissemination of bioarchaeological data, this project will serve as a model for future studies of similar nature, scope, and ambition.

Within this broader context, this project will focus on the archaic city-state of Athens and the social, political, and economic factors that led to the development of the foundations of the modern western society. This study will make a novel and significant contribution to ongoing debates about the formation of the early city-state by targeting the life-histories of non-elite in archaic Athens. The researchers will examine possible changes in residence, diet, health, demographics, and activities in relation to mortuary treatment. How were the non-elite buried? Were they incorporated in formal cemeteries of the city? Was violence sanctioned within the social milieu during times of political upheaval and how is this represented in the mortuary record? By integrating a variety of approaches, including forensic, chemical, and radiocarbon analyses, this study will reconstruct the lived experiences of past people who were not part of the elite as a reflection of broader processes of sociopolitical change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF Public Paragraphs

Our knowledge of ancient Greece prior to the development of democracy rests heavily upon archaeological evidence, especially that from ancient burial grounds.  Thus, the Archaic period (7th and 6th centuries BCE or before the common era) is especially significant, immediately predating the Classical period (5th and 4th BCE) of noted artistic, philosophical, and democratic political achievements. In fact, a long-standing theory for the development of Greek democratic political institutions is based upon the absence of inclusive, non-elite cemeteries for the period prior to the crucial democratic reforms of Cleisthenes (508/507 BCE).  The discovery of the Phaleron Burial Ground (PBG) during salvage excavations in anticipation of constructing the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center (SNFCC) in Kallithea, Greece calls this theory into question.

The PBG dates to the period from the late 8th century to 480 BCE, with the 7th and 6th centuries most prominently represented.  The more than 2000 human remains excavated by the Ephorate of West Attica, Piraeus, and the Islands between 2012 and 2020 therefore comprise an unequaled resource for reconstructing and appreciating the lives of ancient peoples during this important period.  The Phaleron Bioarchaeological Project (PBG), a study of 1100 remains, is multi-scalar, extending from in-depth reconstructions of individual lives to assessments of within site spatial and temporal variation and ending by comparing the PBP to other sites removed in time and space.  

By its very existence, the PBG is strong evidence against the previously dominant argument that early Archaic Athens returned to a conservative political structure during the 7th century BCE, inferred due to the lack of cemeteries other than those for the elite.  Our documentation that the cemetery is a "normal" cemetery with all age/sex groups represented, requires a fresh perspective on these important times. Studies of kinship, based on inherited dental features, suggest that the earlier portions of the PBG were structured by familial relatedness, unlike more recent portions of the site.  Our ancient DNA evidence indicates that the cemetery was not a community cemetery, rather drawing from a larger region, including a few individuals from eastern Asia and north Africa during later periods.  Life histories for some individuals buried bound or shackled were significantly different from those interred without restraints.  The latter group shows little evidence of healed fractured that could be attributed to inter-personal violence; rather these appear accidental and may provide indications of occupation, which will figure within our ongoing activity/occupation studies. The large number of infants who died between birth and one year of age, some with distinctive skeletal indicators of scurvy, signal health challenges for both infants and their mothers.  Our forensic studies, in their final stages, identify postmortem changes have been underappreciated in attributions of traumatic causes of death.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2025
Modified by: Jane E Buikstra

Our knowledge of ancient Greece prior to the development of democracy rests heavily upon archaeological evidence, especially that from ancient burial grounds.Thus, the Archaic period (7thand 6thcenturies BCE or before the common era) is especially significant, immediately predating the Classical period (5thand 4thBCE) of noted artistic, philosophical, and democratic political achievements. The PBG dates to the period from the late 8thcentury to 480 BCE, with the 7thand 6thcenturies most prominently represented.The more than 2000 human remains excavated by the Ephorate of West Attica, Piraeus, and the Islands between 2012 and 2020 therefore comprise an unequaled resource for reconstructing and appreciating the lives of ancient peoples during this important period.The Phaleron Bioarchaeological Project (PBG), a study of 1100 remains, is multi-scalar, extending from in-depth reconstructions of individual lives to assessments of within site spatial and temporal variation and ending by comparing the PBP to other sites removed in time and space.


By its very existence, the PBG is strong evidence against the previously dominant argument that early Archaic Athens returned to a conservative political structure during the 7thcentury BCE, inferred due to the lack of cemeteries other than those for the elite. Our documentation that the cemetery is a "normal" cemetery with all age/sex groups represented, requires a fresh perspective on these important times. Studies of kinship, based on inherited dental features, suggest that the earlier portions of the PBG were structured by familial relatedness, unlike more recent portions of the site. Our ancient DNA evidence indicates that the cemetery wasnota community cemetery, rather drawing from a larger region, including a few individuals from eastern Asia and north Africa during later periods. The large number of infants who died between birth and one year of age, some with distinctive skeletal indicators of scurvy, signal health challenges for both infants and their mothers. Our forensic studies, in their final stages, identify postmortem changes have been underappreciated in attributions of traumatic causes of death.
